question_text: Column-I has statements made by Shanthala; and, Column-II has responses given  by Kanishk.  Column-I  Column-II  P.  This house is in a mess.  1.  Alright, I won’t bring it up during  our conversations.  Q. I am not happy with the marks  given to me.  2.  Well, you can easily look it up.  R. Politics is a subject I avoid talking  about.  3. question_text: Consider the following three relations: Car (model, year, serial, color) Make (maker, model) Own (owner, serial) A tuple in Car represents a speciﬁc car of a given model, made in a given year, with a serial number and a color. Keys are underlined; (owner, serial) together form key for Own. (▷◁denotes natural join) πowner(Own ▷◁(σcolor=“red”(Car ▷◁(σmaker=“ABC”Make)))) Which one of the following options describes what the above expression computes?
option1: All owners of a red car, a car made by ABC, or a red car made by ABC
option2: All owners of more than one car, where at least one car is red and made by ABC
option3: All owners of a red car made by ABC
option4: All red cars made by ABC

Consider designing a linear classiﬁer y = sign(f(x; w, b)), f(x; w, b) = w⊤x + b on a dataset D = {(x1, y1), (x2, y2), . . . , (xN, yN)}, xi ∈Rd, yi ∈{+1, −1}, i = 1, 2, . . . , N. Recall that the sign function outputs +1 if the argument is positive, and −1 if the argument is non-positive. The parameters w and b are updated as per the following training algorithm: wnew = wold + ynxn, bnew = bold + yn whenever sign(f(xn; wold, bold)) ̸= yn. In other words, whenever the classiﬁer wrongly predicts a sample (xn, yn) from the dataset, wold gets updated to wnew, and likewise bold gets updated to bnew. Consider the case (xn, +1), f(xn; wold, bold) < 0. Then
option1: f(xn; wnew, bnew) > f(xn; wold, bold)
option2: f(xn; wnew, bnew) < f(xn; wold, bold)
option3: f(xn; wnew, bnew) = f(xn; wold, bold)
option4: ynf(xn; wold, bold) > 1 Organizing Institute: IIT Roorkee Page 14 of 34  GATE 2025 Data Science & Artiﬁcial Intelligence - DA

question_text: Consider a two-class problem in Rd with class labels red and green. Let µred and µgreen be the means of the two classes. Given test sample x ∈Rd, a classiﬁer calculates the squared Euclidean distance (denoted by ∥· ∥2) between x and the means of the two classes and assigns the class label that the sample x is closest to. That is, the classiﬁer computes f(x) = ∥µred −x∥2 −∥µgreen −x∥2 and assigns the label red to x if f(x) < 0, and green otherwise. Which of the following statements is/are correct?
option1: The sample x = 0 is assigned the label green if ∥µred∥< ∥µgreen∥
option2: f is a linear function of x
option3: f(x) = w⊤x + b, where w and b are functions of µred and µgreen
option4: f is a quadratic polynomial in x Organizing Institute: IIT Roorkee Page 29 of 34  GATE 2025 Data Science & Artiﬁcial Intelligence - DA
